# Statistics I

#### <high>Descriptive statistics</high> with `dplyr`

```{r, echo = T, eval = F}
# Group-summarise idiom
baselers %>%
  group_by(sex, eyecor) %>%
  summarise(
    N = n(),
    age_mean = mean(age),
    height_median = median(height),
    children_max = max(children)
  )
```


#### <high>Simple hypothesis tests</high> with `stats`
```{r, eval = F, echo = T}
# Simple hypothesis test
t.test(baselers$happiness,
       baselers$fitness,
       var.equal = TRUE)
```

]

# `summarise()`

.pull-left45[

Use `summarise()` to create new columns of <high>summary statistics</high>.

The result of `summarise()` is always be a tibble.

Functions used in `summerise()` <high>must return a single value</high>.


```{r, echo = TRUE, eval = FALSE}
data %>%
  summarise(
    NAME = SUMMARY_FUN(A),
    NAME = SUMMARY_FUN(B),
    ...
  )
```

]

.pull-right5[

```{r}
# Calculate summary statistics
baselers %>%
  summarise(
    N = n(),
    age_mean = mean(age),
    height_median = median(height),
    children_max = max(children)
  )
```


]
---

.pull-left45[

# `group_by()` + `summarise()`

Use `group_by()` to <high>group data</high> according to one or more columns.

Then, use `summarise()` to <high>calculate summary statistics</high> for each group.

You can include <high>one or more</high> grouping variables.

```{r, echo = TRUE, eval = FALSE}
data %>%
  group_by(A, B, ...) %>%
  summarise(
    NAME = SUMMARY_FUN(A),
    NAME = SUMMARY_FUN(B),
    ...
  )
```


]

# Full pipeline


Combine <high>tranformation</high>, <high>organization</high>, and <high>aggregating</high> operations at once!

Just use the <high>pipe %>%</high>.

It can easily happen, that your pipes get very long - the <a href="https://github.com/elbersb/tidylog">tidylog package</a> can come in handy for that.


]

.pull-right65[
<br><br><br><br>
```{r echo = TRUE, eval=FALSE}
baselers %>%
  group_by(sex) %>%
  summarise(
    N = n(),
    age_mean = mean(age),
    income_median = median(income, na.rm = TRUE)
  )
```

]

# Basic structure of statistical functions

Statistical functions always require a <high>data frame</high> called `data`, e.g.,...

```{r, echo = FALSE}
baselers %>%
  slice(1:3) %>% select(2:6) %>% knitr::kable(format = 'markdown')
```
<br>
They also require a <high>formula</high> that specifies a <high>dependent</high> variable (y) as a function of one or more <high>independent</high> variables (x1, x2, ...) in the form:

<p align='center'><font size = 6>formula = y ~ x1 + x2 +...</font></p>

]

.pull-right55[

How to create a statistical object:

```{r eval=FALSE}
# Predict income with age and height
my_glm <- glm(formula = XXX ~ XXX + XXX,
              data = XXX)
```


```{r, echo = FALSE}
knitr::include_graphics("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/therbootcamp/Erfurt_2018June/master/_sessions/_image/formula_description.png")
```


]

# Customize formulas

Include <high>additional predictors</high> to formulas by "adding" them with <high>`X`</high> 

```{r eval = FALSE}
# Include multiple terms with +
my_lm <- lm(formula = income X age X height,
            data = baselers)
```


To include, both <high>main effects and interactions</high>, use <high><mono>XXX</mono></high>.

```{r eval = FALSE}
# Include both main effects and interactions for age and height
my_lm <- lm(formula = income X age X height,
            data = baselers)
```

---

# Customize formulas

Include <high>additional predictors</high> to formulas by "adding" them with <high>`+`</high> 

```{r}
# Include multiple terms with +
my_lm <- lm(formula = income ~ age + height,
            data = baselers)
```

To include, both <high>main effects and interactions</high>, use <high><mono>x1*x2</mono></high>.

```{r}
# Include both main effects and interactions for age and height
my_lm <- lm(formula = income ~ age * height,
            data = baselers)
```

# Plotting


```{r, fig.width = 7, fig.height = 5.5, eval = F, echo = TRUE}
ggplot(data = mpg, 
       mapping = aes(x = XXX, 
                     y = XXX)) +
  geom_XXX() + 
  geom_XXX() +
  labs(x = "XXX",
       y = "XXX",
       title = "XXX",
       caption = "XXX") + 
  theme_bw()

```

]
